cleaned_text: Anthroposophical Society in America Organization devoted to the teachings of theosophist and occult mystic [Rudolf Steiner](/people/philosophy-and-religion/other-religious-beliefs-biographies/rudolf-steiner) (1861-1925) whose system is concerned with "wisdom relating to man." Steiner developed his system of thought to speak directly to issues of education, art, dance and body movement, natural foods, and the religious life. The society promotes Steiner's thinking through a number of local and a variety of specialized organizations such as the School of Eurythmy and the Waldorf Institute (260 Hungry Hollow Rd., Spring Valley, [New York](/places/united-states-and-canada/us-political-geography/new-york) 10977), the Bio-Dynamic 769, Congers, [New York](/places/united-states-and-canada/us-political-geography/new-york) 10920). Headquarters Geddes Ave., [Ann Arbor](/places/united-states-and-canada/us-political-geography/ann-arbor), [Michigan](/places/united-states-and-canada/us-political-geography/michigan) 48104-1797. It publishes the quarterly Journal of Anthroposophy. The numerous books by Steiner are published by the Anthroposophical Press [New York](/places/united-states-and-canada/us-political-geography/new-york) 12534). of Activities and Services. New York: Rudolf Steiner Information Center, n.d. Richards, M. C. Toward Wholeness: Rudolf Steiner Education in America. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press, 1980.
